title: Liverpool 2-1 Tottenham: 5 talking points as Reds produce comeback to remain unbeaten
text:

Mohamed Salah took scored his 50th Anfield goal to give Liverpool a pulsating victory, and show they have the quality of Champions.

Salah struck from the spot to record the milestone in just 58 games at the famous old stadium, a record which places him behind only Rodger Hunt in the Reds record books, who got to 50 in 55 games.

And more importantly, it showed Liverpool can stay calm and show the mentality needed of any side who want to win the title, as they fought back after a shock early goal from Tottenham .

The London club belied their poor form with an impressive display, led by Harry Kane who headed home a rebound after 47 seconds, when Son’s deflected shot crashed off the bar.

(Image: Offside via Getty Images)

Liverpool struggled to break down the visitors, and when they did, Paulo Gazzaniga produced a man of the match display in goal to deny them.

But they held their nerve, and kept pressing, with Jordan Henderson levelling after the break, and then Salah scoring from the spot when Serge Aurier brought down Sadio Mane.

Here are the five talking points...

1. Liverpool can handle the pressure

(Image: PA)

There is a conviction about Liverpool that goes far beyond this result against a vibrant and committed Spurs.

This season, nothing seems to rattle them, not going a goal down within the first minute, not the opposition being this dangerous on the break and creating some clear cut chances to place the game beyond them.

Not even spurning five chances in the space of four first half minutes seemed to break their concentration or determination.

They can handle even the worst of scenarios it seems, and keep playing, keep pressing and keep believing.

That is perhaps the most important quality of all in any side which has title pretensions.

2. Different Spurs on show - but why?

(Image: PA)

So much has been said about Spurs this season, and just how poor they have been, but this performance was the old Tottenham, the team that belies the critics and defies the odds against them when they take on richer, bigger spending rivals.

The side which turned up here at Anfield could give anyone a game.

The question is, why does that team not turn up every week these days?

The answer may be simple. This is the biggest stage, with the world watching, and there are TOO many of their players looking to leave.

They will inevitably raise their game for these, to increase their profile.

Maybe Tottenham have made a mistake in letting too many top players get to the end of their contracts.

3. Gazzaniga shows his credentials

(Image: PA)

Liverpool fans have a thing about reserve keepers spoiling the Anfield party.

There was a time during the middle of this decade when it seemed the Reds would be denied every other week by a surprise choice in the opposition goal stepping up and having a blinder.

So it was no surprise to see Paulo Gazzaniga do the same here, as Hugo Lloris’s replacement.

He was outstanding, the first half double save from Salah and then Firmino simply brilliant, and he maintained that resistance in the face of an onslaught.

Given Lloris’s struggles this season, he may fear a return when he recovers from the shoulder injury keeping him out may not be completely automatic.

4, Henderson answers his critics

(Image: REUTERS)

Whichever way you look at it, Jordan Henderson has struggled a little in recent weeks, and his the problem seems to be that sides are now so wary of Liverpool, they play incredibly deep.

Even the likes of Spurs and United have played with nine behind the ball, and that doesn’t help the skipper, because his more advanced midfield role these days means his running ability and aggression is smothered.

So his delight on scoring just after half time was understandable.

It answered some of the criticism aimed his way, criticism that rears its head far too quickly for one of the club’s great servants.

5. Kane is under-rated

(Image: REUTERS)

This may sound a little ridiculous…but Harry Kane is still under-rated.

A huge talent obviously, and yeah, he get recognition enough for that.

But he’s still 26, and is now the third highest goalscorer in Tottenham’s history.

Consider that his breakthrough season wasn’t until 2014-15, so in five and a bit seasons, he’s third in the club’s history.

It’s remarkable. Even more remarkably, he’s now only 92 goals behind Jimmy Greaves.

He deserves to be talked about in the same terms as the all time great, because his record suggests he too is in that bracket.
description: Goals from Jordan Henderson and a Mohamed Salah penalty cancelled out Harry Kane's first-half header
